headline.main: Low-Fat Diet Hasn't Cured Our Medical Ills

docs.abstract: Letter from Dr Michael R Eades and Dr Mary Dan Eades on Jane Brody's Dec 25 Personal Health column on low-carbohydrate diets
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Jane E. Brody (Personal Health, Dec. 25) asserts that low-carbohydrate diets cause ''an increase in uric acid'' that can cause kidney stones and ''a loss of calcium in urine'' that ''raises the risk of osteoporosis.'' But people following such a diet find their uric acid levels falling, not rising. Dr. Herta Spencer, a researcher, has shown that increasing dietary protein does not increase calcium loss.
